advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (DEC. 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Intellivision video games. Realism goes past fiction"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> NORTHSTAR CARDS</strong></font><br><blockquote>Northstar also designed cards for S100 Bus. These cards were used in the Horizon and were also available separately for competing systems.<br> Cards on the photo are:<br> - 16 KB RAM board ($459 assembled)<br> - Micro Disk System (card & interface) to connect Shugart FDD ($799)<br> - Z80A processor board ($259 without EPROM option, $330 with)<br> - Hardware floating point card ($359). </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (DECEMBER 1981)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"At 12 years old, Nicolas discovered he was the terror of the aliens"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> APPLE LOGO (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Apple Logo was a very successful implementation of Logo. It contained some advanced features such as property list and packages, as well as extremely good documentation.<br><br> At the time, Apple thought the Logo language would encourage schools to invest heavily in personal computers for all the class levels.<br> Sadly, Logo never became the revolutionary language that they had hoped for and very few schools taught it to their pupils (except in France).</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> THE FIRST M20 VERSION</strong></font><br><blockquote>This Olivetti ancestor, also called M20, was born in 1920...<br> To note the superb design all the young italian secretaries were in love of! <p class="petitgris">Thanks to Karl-Heinz - www.sharpmz.org</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>One of the first 1982 U.S. Advert.<br><br> Advert said <br><br>THE COMMODORE 64 COULD BE THE MICROCOMPUTER INDUSTRY'S OUTSTANDING NEW PRODUCT INTRODUCTION SINCE THE BIRTH OF THIS INDUSTRY. (Shearson / American Express) <br><br><font color="#666666"> The value of a computer is determined by what it can do. What it can do is largely determined by its memory.<br> The Commodore 64's basic RAM is 64K. This amount of power is unusual in a micro at any price.<br> At $595 it is astonishing.<br> Compared with an Apple II+, for instance, the Commodore 64 offers 33% more power and considerably les than 50% of the cost.<br> Compared with anything else, it's even more impressive...<br><br> If you've been waiting for the "computer revolution", consider it as having arrived... </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FIRST ADVERT (1989)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This brochure was jointly published by Philips and American Interactive Media (the Philips/PolyGram joint venture that was set up to develop CD-i consumer software prior to the launch of the hardware). It was intented to give a general overview of CD-i's functionality in a consumer area. The brochure was presented to visitors of multimedia fairs and business partners at around 1989. The CD-i unit (including the remote control) that is displayed is an artist's impression of a player, it was never actually produced. The first consumer CD-i player, the CDI 910, appeared on the market in the US in October 1991. <br><br> <font color="#666666">Source = <a href="http://www.icdia.org/" target="_blank">The New International CD-i Association</a></font><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.icdia.org/" target="_blank">The New International CD-i Association</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>April 1983 <br><br> Advert said <br><br><font color="#666666"> Simple Isn't it?. The COMPAQ portable computer can do what the IBM Personal Computer does. To go.<br><br> It runs all the popular programs written for the IBM. It works for the same printers ans other peripherals. It even accepts the same optional expansion electronics that give it additional capabilities and fonctionality.<br><br> There's really only one big difference. The COMPAQ computer is designed to travel.<br> Carry the COMPAQ computer from office to office. Carry it home on the weekend. Or take it on business trips...</font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> COMMERCIAL PAMPHLET - PAGE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">thanks to Richard Rogers </p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.sapere.demon.co.uk/computers/honeywell.html" target="_blank">Adrian Wise's website</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN AD #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Large achievement capability and high versatility with 64kb RAM." <p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>www.sharpmz.org</b></p></blockquote>

computer.description:
The PC-9801 was a very popular PC in Japan. PC-9801's design was very similar to IBM-PC, but was slightly extended. VRAM (Video RAM) is strongly extended from original IBM-PC, enabling it to display kanji characters without bitmap memory (as ASCII characters). But I/O systems, Interrupt systems are almost the same.
There were in fact three models : F1, F2 and F3. Whereas F1 & F2 models have only 128k RAM, the F3 had 256 kb RAM and 10 Mb hard-disk built-in.
More info anyone ?
________
Thanks to Nomura Hisayuki for the info
computer.keyboard: Full-stroke keyboard with separated numeric keypad and arrow keys
computer.name: PC 9801 F
computer.sound: One channel beeper. Built-in internal speaker
